awd_titl_txt: Nanogap Electrochemistry of Adsorption-Coupled Electron Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, with co-funding from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A Program, of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Shigeru Amemiya of the University of Pittsburgh is developing new electrochemical methods that allow for the separate study of electron transfer and coupled adsorption events at novel nanometer-sized electrodes. This project focuses on gaining an advanced understanding of adsorption-coupled electron transfer, which plays a vital role in numerous electrochemical energy devices, such as fuel cells, batteries, solar cells, and supercapacitors. Reliable determination of rate and energy parameters is possible due to the creation of new research tools. Students from underrepresented groups gain interdisciplinary training in the research and undergraduate laboratory environments, as a result of their participating in cross-cutting research.  

This project is focused on the quantitative study of adsorption-coupled electron transfer as the key step of electrochemical technologies that span electrocatalysis, electrodeposition, and electroanalysis. New nanoelectrochemical methods developed in the Amemiya laboratory provide an opportunity to kinetically resolve adsorption-coupled electron transfer into its elementary steps. Specifically, nanogap voltammetry with a scanning electrochemical microscope affords a path to separately determine the dynamics of inner-sphere and outer-sphere electron transfer, surface adsorption, and even coupled chemical reactions. Reliable reaction parameters can be obtained by employing clean electrodes that maintain vacuum-level surface cleanliness in air and solution, as a result of new methods developed by Professor Amemiya's research group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed new electrochemical methods to separately investigate electron transfer and coupled adsorption reactions for redox-active molecules at nanometer-sized electrodes. Adsorption-coupled electron transfer reactions are ubiquitous and crucial in various fields of electrochemistry, e.g., electrocatalysis, electrodeposition, and electroanalysis, to play a vital role in numerous electrochemical energy devices, such as fuel cells, batteries, solar cells, and supercapacitors. Specifically. we developed transient nanogap voltammetry based on scanning electrochemical microscopy to discriminate between the concerted and non-concerted mechanisms of adsorption-coupled electron transfer reactions experimentally for the first time. To reliably determine the molecular mechanism, we uniquely prepared metal and carbon electrodes with surfaces that remained clean of interfering species. In addition, we determined thermodynamic and kinetic parameters of adsorption-coupled electron transfer reliably from complicated electrochemical data. This unprecedented accomplishment was made possible by the development of not only new experimental tools but also advanced computer simulation. We enabled the finite element simulation of adsorption-coupled electron-transfer reactions in collaboration with a French research group as a world expert in electrochemical simulation. We developed a Python program to systematically vary reaction parameters for the finite element simulation with high flexibility. A few hundred voltammograms were simulated overnight and then plotted and analyzed instantaneously by a home-written Python program. The finite element simulation and Python programs are posted on our website. Students from underrepresented groups gained interdisciplinary training in internationally collaborative research as a result of their participating in cutting-edge nanoscale electrochemical investigations and using advanced electrochemical simulation software. Overall, three graduate students, one visiting Master?s student from India, and five female undergraduate students were trained through this project as a new generation of electrochemists, a highly demanded component of the interdisciplinary STEM field. Two graduate students including a female obtained their Ph.D. degrees during this support.

 


Last Modified: 07/05/2023
Modified by: Shigeru Amemiya
